body.p: This section is of special interest if you are creating a CSS stylesheet for a custom XML document. For HTML, already defines the needed selectors for the table element.
This is an example of a very simple table in an XML document:
body.codeblock: <tbl> <caption>A table.</caption> <rw> <c rspan="2"> Spans vertically </c> <c> Other cell </c> <c> Other cell </c> </rw> <rw> <c cspan="2"> Other cell, spanning to the right </c> </rw> </tbl>

section.title: Defining the Column and Row Span
section.p: The processor needs to know how the cells span multiple rows or columns. For this, there are two properties available: table-column-span and table-row-span.

section.title: Repeating Headers and Footers
section.p: Any element marked with either the table-header-group or table-footer-group property is automatically repeated when a table is split over a sequence of pages. It is required that they contain only elements with the display property set to table-row.

section.title: Rotating Tables
section.p: There are cases where you have large tables and you need to rotate them to make them fit on your page. For instance, the default page is portrait, but because you have a table with many columns (and thus very wide), it would bleed to the right of the page.

The page is now landscape and you probably also need to change the headers and footers to match this new orientation. One way of doing this is to move the header content from the @top-left, @top-center, and @top-right rules into page margin boxes from the right, and apply a transform property on them.
